text:
After a month in Tokyo, Nikko (日光) was
everything we were hoping for!

We knew we were in for a treat on the train
ride over once we started seeing forests and

mountains all around us and the town did not
disappoint.

Nikko was the breath of fresh air we were
looking for; during our visit we hiked through

shrines and temples, cruised a beautiful lake
at the base of a volcano, sampled some local

dishes featuring tofu skin, and basically
had the perfect city break.

So in this travel guide, we are going sharing
some of our favorite things to do in Nikko,
so you too can plan your weekend escape!

Okay so it is our first morning of sightseeing
here in Nikko (日光) and we have decided
to go in search of temples.

So we are going to get on the bus that does
the temple loop.

There is a whole bunch of shrines and temples
located right in the forest.

So it should be a lot of fun the bus is about
to come.
Let's go.

We are going to be doing the Heritage Loop
and we are using our Nikko four day passes

which give us free transportation in the city
to a lot of the major attractions so this
is perfect.
Yeah.

Here you can see the map that shows you all
of the different temples and shrines.

So we are going to try to hit up as many as
we can.

The tale.

Like the water is so so clear here.

The Shinkyo Bridge (神橋) you see today was constructed
in 1636, but a bridge of some form has stood

on this very same spot for much longer...even
if its origins are a bit unclear.

So just across the bridge we just finished

Nikko.

Nikko is home to numerous Shinto shrines and
Buddhist temples.

We focused our visit on the Toshogu Shrine (東照宮),
which we’ll show you next.
So we finally reached the temple.

Next up we are visiting the Toshogu Shrine (東照宮)
which is actually a pretty large complex with
a lot to see.

Admission to this shrine was not included
in our Nikko four day pass so we had to pay
1300 Yen per person.

Um which seems a little pricey but I mean
this place is proving to be quite impressive
so far.

Now for a quick history lesson; the Toshogu
shrine (東照宮) is the final resting place of Tokugawa
Ieyasu, the founder of the Tokugawa shogunate.

This was Japan’s last feudal military government,
with the shogun as its leader.

Most of what you see here today was built
by Iemitsu, the third shogun and grandson
of Ieyasu.

Kegon (華厳の滝) is Nikko’s most famous waterfall.

It stands almost 100 meters tall and the waters
that feed it comes directly from Lake Chuzenji.

There are two viewing decks: a free one, and
a paid one at the base of the waterfall which
is accessed by an elevator.
Check out those views guys.
It is pretty insane.

We decided to take the elevator because it
is the only way to get this close and to get
the views just like that.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Well worth it.

We were feeling pretty hungry after all that
sightseeing, so we decided to find a restaurant
serving up the local specialty: yuba!
Or tofu skin.

I ordered the ramen with yuba and Sam got
the udon with yuba.

The tofu skin was fluffy and absorbed all
the flavours of the miso - it was delicious.

Also, my bowl was bigger, so we know who ordered
right this time!
Yeah, so the yuba is wonderful.

And also I really like the broth for this

Lake Chuzenji (中禅寺湖) is located at the foot of Mount
Nantai.

So most of the onsen here are located inside

to access them and they are only open during

So we're just going to hangout and see if

Yumoto is a small hot springs town that is
located in part of Nikko National Park.

Yumoto literally means ‘origin of hot water’
and as you’ll see, it lives up to its name.

The Senjogahara Marshland (戦場ヶ原) covers the area
between Lake Chuzenji (中禅寺湖) and Yumoto Onsen.

It offers some great hiking opportunities
within Nikko National Park, though we only
covered a fraction of it.

The Senjogahara Plateau Nature Trail follows
the Yukawa River and can be completed in two-and-a-half
to three hours.
And that’s a wrap for our Nikko travel guide!

This proved to be the perfect weekend escape
from Tokyo.

We visited everything you see here over the
course of 2 days, but this place is even better
if you can come for 3 or 4 nights.

Nature abounds, there are countless shrines
and temples to visit, plus the local cuisine
was exquisite!

Now you have a few ideas of things to do around
Nikko (日光) when you visit.

Wishing you happy travels and see you next
time!
